msgSnippet: So said  Steven Taschuk  on  2002-11-14 ... I had been thinking of writing one that included things like deadlock detection and the like, but I never got
messageBody:
So said Steven Taschuk on 2002-11-14

>Quoth J. B. Rainsberger:
> [...]
>> Now, had I been in control of my own DDL, I might not have written
>> those tests; however, since I designed my component to abstract away
>> persistence, I wrote those tests to ensure that my in-memory
>> implementation of the persistent objects worked correctly. It needed to
>> reject the same kinds of duplicates that the database would.
> [...]
>
>Vaguely on this subject:
>
>Does there exist a JDBC driver for a transient in-memory store?
>I'd like to use such a thing as a mock database for testing that
>code makes proper use of JDBC. Testing such things as:
> - Proper use of JDBC escapes (exposed when the driver uses some weird
> syntax for various kinds of literals).
> - Adaptation to (or graceful failure in) the absence of certain SQL
> features.
> - Graceful failure in the case of violation of data constraints.
>
>I also imagine configuring the driver to emulate various real
>drivers, to test portability across databases.
>
>Any suggestions?

I had been thinking of writing one that included things like deadlock detection and the like, but I never got around to it. I got another job, instead. :)
